page.title: List of accidents and incidents involving military aircraft (2000âpresent)

rev.diff:
Line 32: Line 32:
*16 February - A [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] [[Douglas A-4 Skyhawk|Douglas A-4K Skyhawk]], ''NZ6211'', from [[No. 2 Squadron RNZAF]] crashes near {{HMAS|Albatross|air station|6}} in [[New South Wales]] while practicing maneuvers for an upcoming air show, killing the aircraft's pilot.<ref>http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/423466/29845</ref><ref>Allport, Dave, "''Attrition''", Air Forces Monthly, Stamfords, Lincs., UK, Number 157, April 2001, page 93.</ref>
*16 February - A [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] [[Douglas A-4 Skyhawk|Douglas A-4K Skyhawk]], ''NZ6211'', from [[No. 2 Squadron RNZAF]] crashes near {{HMAS|Albatross|air station|6}} in [[New South Wales]] while practicing maneuvers for an upcoming air show, killing the aircraft's pilot.<ref>http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/423466/29845</ref><ref>Allport, Dave, "''Attrition''", Air Forces Monthly, Stamfords, Lincs., UK, Number 157, April 2001, page 93.</ref>
*3 March - A [[United States National Guard]] [[Short C-23 Sherpa|Short C-23B+ Sherpa]] ([[Shorts 360]]), ''93-1336'', of Florida Army National Guard Det. 1 H/171st AVN, based at Lakeland Linder Regional Airport, crashes during heavy rainstorm around 1100 hrs. in [[Unadilla, Georgia|Unadilla]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in the United States. All 21 people on board are killed. Aircraft was en route from [[Hurlburt Field]], [[Florida]] to [[NAS Oceana]], [[Virginia]] with Virginia Beach-based [[RED HORSE]] detachment on board who had been training at Hurlburt.<ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, compiled by Dave Allport, May 2001, Number 158, page 77.</ref>
*3 March - A [[United States National Guard]] [[Short C-23 Sherpa|Short C-23B+ Sherpa]] ([[Shorts 360]]), ''93-1336'', of Florida Army National Guard Det. 1 H/171st AVN, based at Lakeland Linder Regional Airport, crashes during heavy rainstorm around 1100 hrs. in [[Unadilla, Georgia|Unadilla]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in the United States. All 21 people on board are killed. Aircraft was en route from [[Hurlburt Field]], [[Florida]] to [[NAS Oceana]], [[Virginia]] with Virginia Beach-based [[RED HORSE]] detachment on board who had been training at Hurlburt.<ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, compiled by Dave Allport, May 2001, Number 158, page 77.</ref>
â
[[File:EP-3 Hainan Island 2001.jpg|thumb|right|EP-3E on Hainan Island]]
 
*1 April - '''[[Hainan Island incident]]'''- An American [[Lockheed EP-3|Lockheed EP-3E]] Aries II surveillance plane, BuNo ''156511'', coded 'PR-32', of [[VQ-1]], collided with a Chinese [[Shenyang J-8|Shenyang J-8IID]] fighter jet, reported as ''81192'', and was forced to make an emergency landing at [[Lingshui]] air base on [[Hainan]] Island, China. The U.S. crew was detained for 10 days; the Chinese fighter pilot, Wang Wei, was reported missing and presumed dead. The Chinese refused to let the Orion be flown out, so it was dismantled and transported on chartered [[Antonov An-124|Antonov An-124-100]] of Polyot.<ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, May 2001, Number 158, page 4.</ref><ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, June 2001, Number 159, page 79</ref><ref>Dawes, Alan, "Spies in the Sky!", ''Air International'', September 2001, Volume 61, Number 3, page 175.</ref>
*1 April - '''[[Hainan Island incident]]'''- An American [[Lockheed EP-3|Lockheed EP-3E]] Aries II surveillance plane, BuNo ''156511'', coded 'PR-32', of [[VQ-1]], collided with a Chinese [[Shenyang J-8|Shenyang J-8IID]] fighter jet, reported as ''81192'', and was forced to make an emergency landing at [[Lingshui]] air base on [[Hainan]] Island, China. The U.S. crew was detained for 10 days; the Chinese fighter pilot, Wang Wei, was reported missing and presumed dead. The Chinese refused to let the Orion be flown out, so it was dismantled and transported on chartered [[Antonov An-124|Antonov An-124-100]] of Polyot.<ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, May 2001, Number 158, page 4.</ref><ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, June 2001, Number 159, page 79</ref><ref>Dawes, Alan, "Spies in the Sky!", ''Air International'', September 2001, Volume 61, Number 3, page 175.</ref>
*4 April - A [[Sudan Air Force]] [[Antonov An-24]] '''[[2001 Sudanese Air Force Antonov AN-24 crash|crashes]]''' during a sandstorm in Adar Yeil, [[Sudan]]. Of the 30 people on board, 14 were killed; among them, Sudan's deputy defense minister as well as other high-ranking officers.
*4 April - A [[Sudan Air Force]] [[Antonov An-24]] '''[[2001 Sudanese Air Force Antonov AN-24 crash|crashes]]''' during a sandstorm in Adar Yeil, [[Sudan]]. Of the 30 people on board, 14 were killed; among them, Sudan's deputy defense minister as well as other high-ranking officers.
